response.answer_text: What is the thing in the picture above? that’s right, it was a printing press. Maybe this thing is underrated nowadays and even was only a relic. But what people do not know of it’s importance is that this thing made of wood, invented by a German from Mainz, was the basis and the origin of printing itself. Well, this thing made life much more easier for humankind, especially Europeans at the time. But, why? Well, before the the existence of this thing, many books were written by monks in most monasteries, and that was not efficient. Why? Because writing books with ink is really time consuming, and also it does not allow books to be massively produced.So then this guy:  (Yes this is Johannes Gutenberg, the inventor of this thing) Who happens to have a financial problem of making polished metal mirrors , suddenly come up with the idea of inventing a printing press. Legend has it, that the idea came to him like “a ray of light”. So by 1450, his printing machine were already set to work and one of the first thing he printed was a German poem. Although most of his works were unidentified and unknown, one of his most famous works of him is this:  Yeah, that’s right. It was Gutenberg’s bible whom he made in 1455, No he didn’t made the bible himself. But he copied it. “In 1455, Gutenberg completed copies of a beautifully executed folio Bible (Biblia Sacra), with 42 lines on each page. Copies sold for 30 florins each, [24] which was roughly three years' wages for an average clerk. Nonetheless, it was significantly cheaper than a manuscript Bible that could take a single scribe over a year to prepare. After printing, some copies were rubricated or hand-illuminated in the same elegant way as manuscript Bibles from the same period.” As the statement said, he clearly copies a beautifully executed folio Bible. which is a great thing, as it allows Europeans for the first time, mass produce the Bible, which is a really great thing. Eventually, it shows it’s own blossom starting in the 16th century and was used for most religious uses, for example: The spread of the Protestant Reformation was really aided by the printing press, as it mass printing Luther’s 95 Theses. Had the Printing Press was never invented, the spread of the Protestantism, especially Luther’s doctrines (Lutheranism), will spread very slowly. Which makes it spread much more slower and also it’s popularity was not that significant for the whole Europe to be famous.  “This the portrait of Martin Luther, the father of the Protestant Movement”. Recently I read an article which mentioned a new device developed by MIT which is being called as a ‘Mind Reading Device’ that lets the user communicate with their device without actually speaking loud or any had movements.  The above photograph shows the device which is officially named (atleast for now) as ‘Alter Ego’. According to a statement released by MIT Media Lab, the device would allow users to send silent commands to the headset simply by thinking of a word. A neural network would translate the muscle movements to speech and do the user's bidding — totally hands- and voice-free.
